segment.source: Web authentication broker
segment.target: Web authentication broker

segment.source: This article explains how to connect your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app to an online identity provider that uses authentication protocols like OpenID or OAuth, such as Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Instagram, and so on.
segment.target: This article explains how to connect your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app to an online identity provider that uses authentication protocols like OpenID or OAuth, such as Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Instagram, and so on.

segment.source: Web authentication broker
segment.target: Web authentication broker

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article explains how to connect your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app to an online identity provider that uses authentication protocols like OpenID or OAuth, such as Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Instagram, and so on.
segment.target: This article explains how to connect your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app to an online identity provider that uses authentication protocols like OpenID or OAuth, such as Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Instagram, and so on.

segment.source: The AuthenticateAsync method sends a request to the online identity provider and gets back an access token that describes the provider resources to which the app has access.
segment.target: The AuthenticateAsync method sends a request to the online identity provider and gets back an access token that describes the provider resources to which the app has access.

segment.source: Note For a complete, working code sample, clone the WebAuthenticationBroker repo on GitHub.
segment.target: Note For a complete, working code sample, clone the WebAuthenticationBroker repo on GitHub.

segment.source: Register your app with your online provider
segment.target: Register your app with your online provider

segment.source: You must register your app with the online identity provider to which you want to connect.
segment.target: You must register your app with the online identity provider to which you want to connect.

segment.source: You can find out how to register your app from the identity provider.
segment.target: You can find out how to register your app from the identity provider.

segment.source: After registering, the online provider typically gives you an Id or secret key for your app.
segment.target: After registering, the online provider typically gives you an Id or secret key for your app.

segment.source: Build the authentication request URI
segment.target: Build the authentication request URI

segment.source: The request URI consists of the address where you send the authentication request to your online provider appended with other required information, such as an app ID or secret, a redirect URI where the user is sent after completing authentication, and the expected response type.
segment.target: The request URI consists of the address where you send the authentication request to your online provider appended with other required information, such as an app ID or secret, a redirect URI where the user is sent after completing authentication, and the expected response type.

segment.source: You can find out from your provider what parameters are required.
segment.target: You can find out from your provider what parameters are required.

segment.source: The request URI is sent as the requestUri parameter of the AuthenticateAsync method.
segment.target: The request URI is sent as the requestUri parameter of the AuthenticateAsync method.

segment.source: It must be a secure address (it must start with https://)
segment.target: It must be a secure address (it must start with https://)

segment.source: The following example shows how to build the request URI.
segment.target: The following example shows how to build the request URI.

segment.source: Connect to the online provider
segment.target: Connect to the online provider

segment.source: You call the AuthenticateAsync method to connect to the online identity provider and get an access token.
segment.target: You call the AuthenticateAsync method to connect to the online identity provider and get an access token.

segment.source: The method takes the URI constructed in the previous step as the requestUri parameter, and a URI to which you want the user to be redirected as the callbackUri parameter.
segment.target: The method takes the URI constructed in the previous step as the requestUri parameter, and a URI to which you want the user to be redirected as the callbackUri parameter.

segment.source: In addition to AuthenticateAsync, the Windows.Security.Authentication.Web namespace contains an AuthenticateAndContinue method.
segment.target: In addition to AuthenticateAsync, the Windows.Security.Authentication.Web namespace contains an AuthenticateAndContinue method.

segment.source: Do not call this method.
segment.target: Do not call this method.

segment.source: It is designed for apps targeting Windows Phone 8.1 only and is deprecated starting with Windows 10.
segment.target: It is designed for apps targeting Windows Phone 8.1 only and is deprecated starting with Windows 10.

segment.source: Connecting with single sign-on (SSO).
segment.target: Connecting with single sign-on (SSO).

segment.source: By default, Web authentication broker does not allow cookies to persist.
segment.target: By default, Web authentication broker does not allow cookies to persist.

segment.source: Because of this, even if the app user indicates that they want to stay logged in (for example, by selecting a check box in the provider's login dialog), they will have to login each time they want to access resources for that provider.
segment.target: Because of this, even if the app user indicates that they want to stay logged in (for example, by selecting a check box in the provider's login dialog), they will have to login each time they want to access resources for that provider.

segment.source: To login with SSO, your online identity provider must have enabled SSO for Web authentication broker, and your app must call the overload of AuthenticateAsync that does not take a callbackUri parameter.
segment.target: To login with SSO, your online identity provider must have enabled SSO for Web authentication broker, and your app must call the overload of AuthenticateAsync that does not take a callbackUri parameter.

segment.source: To support SSO, the online provider must allow you to register a redirect URI in the form appSID, where appSID is the SID for your app.
segment.target: To support SSO, the online provider must allow you to register a redirect URI in the form appSID, where appSID is the SID for your app.

segment.source: You can find your app's SID from the app developer page for your app, or by calling the GetCurrentApplicationCallbackUri method.
segment.target: You can find your app's SID from the app developer page for your app, or by calling the GetCurrentApplicationCallbackUri method.

segment.source: Debugging
segment.target: Debugging

segment.source: There are several ways to troubleshoot the web authentication broker APIs, including reviewing operational logs and reviewing web requests and responses using Fiddler.
segment.target: There are several ways to troubleshoot the web authentication broker APIs, including reviewing operational logs and reviewing web requests and responses using Fiddler.

segment.source: Operational logs
segment.target: Operational logs

segment.source: Often you can determine what is not working by using the operational logs.
segment.target: Often you can determine what is not working by using the operational logs.

segment.source: There is a dedicated event log channel Microsoft-Windows-WebAuth\\Operational that allows website developers to understand how their web pages are being processed by the Web authentication broker.
segment.target: There is a dedicated event log channel Microsoft-Windows-WebAuth\\Operational that allows website developers to understand how their web pages are being processed by the Web authentication broker.

segment.source: To enable it, launch eventvwr.exe and enable Operational log under the Application and Services\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WebAuth.
segment.target: To enable it, launch eventvwr.exe and enable Operational log under the Application and Services\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WebAuth.

segment.source: Also, the Web authentication broker appends a unique string to the user agent string to identify itself on the web server.
segment.target: Also, the Web authentication broker appends a unique string to the user agent string to identify itself on the web server.

segment.source: The string is "MSAuthHost/1.0".
segment.target: The string is "MSAuthHost/1.0".

segment.source: Note that the version number may change in the future, so you should not to depend on that version number in your code.
segment.target: Note that the version number may change in the future, so you should not to depend on that version number in your code.

segment.source: An example of the full user agent string, followed by full debugging steps, is as follows.
segment.target: An example of the full user agent string, followed by full debugging steps, is as follows.

segment.source: Enable operational logs.
segment.target: Enable operational logs.

segment.source: Run Contoso social application.
segment.target: Run Contoso social application.

segment.source: event viewer displaying the webauth operational logs
segment.target: event viewer displaying the webauth operational logs

segment.source: The generated logs entries can be used to understand the behavior of Web authentication broker in greater detail.
segment.target: The generated logs entries can be used to understand the behavior of Web authentication broker in greater detail.

segment.source: In this case, these can include:
segment.target: In this case, these can include:

segment.source: Navigation Start: Logs when the AuthHost is started and contains information about the start and termination URLs.
segment.target: Navigation Start: Logs when the AuthHost is started and contains information about the start and termination URLs.

segment.source: illustrates the details of navigation start
segment.target: illustrates the details of navigation start

segment.source: Navigation Complete: Logs the completion of loading a web page.
segment.target: Navigation Complete: Logs the completion of loading a web page.

segment.source: Meta Tag: Logs when a meta-tag is encountered including the details.
segment.target: Meta Tag: Logs when a meta-tag is encountered including the details.

segment.source: Navigation Terminate: Navigation terminated by the user.
segment.target: Navigation Terminate: Navigation terminated by the user.

segment.source: Navigation Error: AuthHost encounters a navigation error at a URL including HttpStatusCode.
segment.target: Navigation Error: AuthHost encounters a navigation error at a URL including HttpStatusCode.

segment.source: Navigation End: Terminating URL is encountered.
segment.target: Navigation End: Terminating URL is encountered.

segment.source: Fiddler
segment.target: Fiddler

segment.source: The Fiddler web debugger can be used with apps.
segment.target: The Fiddler web debugger can be used with apps.

segment.source: Since the AuthHost runs in its own app container to give it the private network capability, you must set a registry key: Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00
segment.target: Since the AuthHost runs in its own app container to give it the private network capability, you must set a registry key: Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

segment.source: HKEY\_LOCAL\_MACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindows NTCurrentVersionImage File Execution Optionsauthhost.exeEnablePrivateNetwork = 00000001
segment.target: HKEY\_LOCAL\_MACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindows NTCurrentVersionImage File Execution Optionsauthhost.exeEnablePrivateNetwork = 00000001

segment.source: Add a rule for the AuthHost as this is what is generating the outbound traffic.
segment.target: Add a rule for the AuthHost as this is what is generating the outbound traffic.

segment.source: Add a firewall rule for incoming traffic to Fiddler.
segment.target: Add a firewall rule for incoming traffic to Fiddler.
